title: 107_s2458
content: Establishment of initiatives for predominantly Muslim countries. The Congress finds that in predominantly Muslim countries, negative opinions of the United States and its foreign policy are distorted by misinformation and propaganda, which is prejudicial to US interests. In predominantly Muslim countries, negative opinions of the United States and its foreign policy are prejudicial to US interests. To enhance a positive image, programs promoting familiarity with American society and values among the general public and select audiences in these countries should be established by the Secretary of State. The Department of State offers programs for foreign journalists and journalism students to improve professionalism. Additionally, a demonstration program assists foreign governments in upgrading public library systems. The Department of State offers programs to upgrade public library systems, improve literacy, and support education. The program includes training in library sciences and English language teaching opportunities to advance American values like freedom and democracy. The Secretary aims to expand sister city partnerships between US and foreign municipalities to promote global cooperation at the community level, focusing on economic development, municipal cooperation, health care, youth programs, disability advocacy, emergency preparedness, and humanitarian assistance. The Secretary will establish a program for middle and secondary school students from diverse countries to visit the United States for cultural and educational activities during school holidays, not exceeding 4 weeks. Coordination with US schools for additional activities is encouraged. The Secretary will establish a program for school-based activities and interactions, including direct school-to-school linkages. Additionally, efforts will be made to increase awards under the Fulbright exchange program for individuals studying, teaching, or conducting research in predominantly Muslim countries. The Secretary aims to increase awards for scholars and teachers from predominantly Muslim countries, including Hubert H. Humphrey Fellowships. Programs will be carried out under specific acts. The Secretary will establish a database of American and foreign alumni of exchange programs to promote networking and communication. Additionally, a report will be made on the inclusion of freedom and democracy advocates in educational and cultural exchange programs. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of this Act's enactment on the implementation of a specific section of the Human Rights, Refugee, and Other Foreign Relations Provisions Act of 1996. The report will detail the number of grants for exchange programs to certain countries, efforts to ensure inclusion of freedom and democracy supporters in the selection process, and an evaluation of US exchange programs. The report to Congress will include details on the number of grants for exchange programs to specific countries, efforts to include supporters of freedom and democracy in the selection process, and an evaluation of the openness of US exchange programs to such supporters. SEC. 4. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not authorize visas or admission to the US for inadmissible aliens. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $35,000,000 is authorized for the Department of State for fiscal years 2003 and 2004. SEC. 6. SECRETARY DEFINED. "Secretary" in this Act refers to the Secretary of State.
